trans-unit.source: Learn about the latest Azure Guest OS Releases | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Learn about the latest Azure Guest OS Releases | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The latest release news and SDK compatibility for Azure Cloud Services Guest OS.
trans-unit.target: The latest release news and SDK compatibility for Azure Cloud Services Guest OS.

trans-unit.source: Azure Guest OS Releases and SDK Compatibility Matrix
trans-unit.target: Azure Guest OS Releases and SDK Compatibility Matrix

trans-unit.source: Provides you with up-to-date information about the latest Azure Guest OS releases for Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Provides you with up-to-date information about the latest Azure Guest OS releases for Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: This information will help you plan your upgrade path before a a Guest OS is disabled.
trans-unit.target: This information will help you plan your upgrade path before a a Guest OS is disabled.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] This page applies to Cloud Services web and worker roles, which run on top of a Guest OS.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] This page applies to Cloud Services web and worker roles, which run on top of a Guest OS.

trans-unit.source: It does not apply to IaaS Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: It does not apply to IaaS Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: If you configure your roles to use automatic Guest OS updates as described in [Azure Guest OS Update Settings][], it is not vital that you read this page.
trans-unit.target: If you configure your roles to use automatic Guest OS updates as described in [Azure Guest OS Update Settings][], it is not vital that you read this page.

trans-unit.source: > [AZURE.TIP] Subscribe to the [Guest OS Update RSS Feed][rss] to receive the most timely notification on all Guest OS changes.
trans-unit.target: > [AZURE.TIP] Subscribe to the [Guest OS Update RSS Feed][rss] to receive the most timely notification on all Guest OS changes.

trans-unit.source: Changes mentioned on that feed will be integrated into this page approximately every week.
trans-unit.target: Changes mentioned on that feed will be integrated into this page approximately every week.

trans-unit.source:
News Updates
###### **August 14 2015** August Guest OS rollout is starting today Aug 14 2015, and projected to be released on Sep 11 2015.
trans-unit.target:
News Updates
###### **August 14 2015** August Guest OS rollout is starting today Aug 14 2015, and projected to be released on Sep 11 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **August 7 2015** Guest OS versions 4.22, 3.29, 2.41 were released on August 7 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **August 7 2015** Guest OS versions 4.22, 3.29, 2.41 were released on August 7 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **July 14 2015** July Guest OS rollout is starting today July 14 2015, and projected to be released on August 14 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **July 14 2015** July Guest OS rollout is starting today July 14 2015, and projected to be released on August 14 2015.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS versions 4.21, 3.28, 2.40 were released on July 9 2015.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS versions 4.21, 3.28, 2.40 were released on July 9 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **June 15 2015** June Guest OS rollout is starting today June 15 2015, and projected to be released on July 9 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **June 15 2015** June Guest OS rollout is starting today June 15 2015, and projected to be released on July 9 2015.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS versions 4.20, 3.27, 2.39 were released on June 12 2015.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS versions 4.20, 3.27, 2.39 were released on June 12 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **May 20 2015** May Guest OS rollout is starting today May 20 2015, and projected to be released on June 12 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **May 20 2015** May Guest OS rollout is starting today May 20 2015, and projected to be released on June 12 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **April 17 2015** Guest OS versions 4.19, 3.26, 2.38 were released today.
trans-unit.target: ###### **April 17 2015** Guest OS versions 4.19, 3.26, 2.38 were released today.

trans-unit.source: This release contains [MS15-034](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/security/MS15-034), a **critical** patch for Windows HTTP Servers.
trans-unit.target: This release contains [MS15-034](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/security/MS15-034), a **critical** patch for Windows HTTP Servers.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS versions 4.17, 3.24, 2.36 will be disabled on May 17 2015.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS versions 4.17, 3.24, 2.36 will be disabled on May 17 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **April 6 2015** Guest OS versions 4.18, 3.25, 2.37 were released on April 2 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **April 6 2015** Guest OS versions 4.18, 3.25, 2.37 were released on April 2 2015.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS versions 4.16, 3.23, 2.35 will be disabled on May 2 2015.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS versions 4.16, 3.23, 2.35 will be disabled on May 2 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **March 11 2015** Guest OS versions 4.17, 3.24, and 2.36 were released on March 9 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **March 11 2015** Guest OS versions 4.17, 3.24, and 2.36 were released on March 9 2015.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS versions 4.15, 3.22, and 2.34 have had their disable date set to April 9 2015.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS versions 4.15, 3.22, and 2.34 have had their disable date set to April 9 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **Jan 29 2015** Guest OS versions 4.14, 4.13, 3.21, 3.20, 2.33, 2.32 (released in November) have had their Disable Date pushed back.
trans-unit.target: ###### **Jan 29 2015** Guest OS versions 4.14, 4.13, 3.21, 3.20, 2.33, 2.32 (released in November) have had their Disable Date pushed back.

trans-unit.source: The Guest OS release matrix below has been updated.
trans-unit.target: The Guest OS release matrix below has been updated.

trans-unit.source: ###### **Jan 13 2015, Updated Jan 15 2015** The December Guest OS was released on Jan 14 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **Jan 13 2015, Updated Jan 15 2015** The December Guest OS was released on Jan 14 2015.

trans-unit.source: ###### **Jan 13 2015** The January Guest OS deployment is projected to start on or after Jan 19 2015 updating cloud services running on automatic update.
trans-unit.target: ###### **Jan 13 2015** The January Guest OS deployment is projected to start on or after Jan 19 2015 updating cloud services running on automatic update.

trans-unit.source: The January Guest OS will be released for deployment sometime in February.
trans-unit.target: The January Guest OS will be released for deployment sometime in February.

trans-unit.source: It will disable SSL v3.0 by default as suggested in the January security update.
trans-unit.target: It will disable SSL v3.0 by default as suggested in the January security update.

trans-unit.source: This article will be updated when more information is available.
trans-unit.target: This article will be updated when more information is available.

trans-unit.source: As [previously announced][ssl3 announcement], the January Security update to the PaaS Guest OS will disable SSL v3.0 support by default as recommended by [Microsoft Security Advisory 3009008][].
trans-unit.target: As [previously announced][ssl3 announcement], the January Security update to the PaaS Guest OS will disable SSL v3.0 support by default as recommended by [Microsoft Security Advisory 3009008][].

trans-unit.source: This change will come in addition to all other monthly security updates.
trans-unit.target: This change will come in addition to all other monthly security updates.

trans-unit.source: PaaS customers with automatic Updates enabled can validate whether there is an application compatibility impact when SSL v3.0 is disabled by running this [Fix it script][ssl3-fixit] which will proactively disable SSL v3.0 support.
trans-unit.target: PaaS customers with automatic Updates enabled can validate whether there is an application compatibility impact when SSL v3.0 is disabled by running this [Fix it script][ssl3-fixit] which will proactively disable SSL v3.0 support.

trans-unit.source: ###### **Dec 16, 2014. Updated Jan 7 2015** The December Guest OS release is projected to start on or after Jan 9 2015.
trans-unit.target: ###### **Dec 16, 2014. Updated Jan 7 2015** The December Guest OS release is projected to start on or after Jan 9 2015.

trans-unit.source:
Guest OS Release Information
This section lists the currently supported Guest OS versions.
trans-unit.target:
Guest OS Release Information
This section lists the currently supported Guest OS versions.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS families and versions have a release date, a disabled date, and an expiration date.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS families and versions have a release date, a disabled date, and an expiration date.

trans-unit.source: As of the release date, a Guest OS version can be manually selected in the management portal.
trans-unit.target: As of the release date, a Guest OS version can be manually selected in the management portal.

trans-unit.source: A Guest OS is removed from the management portal on or after its "disabled" date.
trans-unit.target: A Guest OS is removed from the management portal on or after its "disabled" date.

trans-unit.source: It is then "in transition" but is supported with limited ability to update a deployment.
trans-unit.target: It is then "in transition" but is supported with limited ability to update a deployment.

trans-unit.source: The expiration date is when a version or family is scheduled to be removed from the Azure system completely.
trans-unit.target: The expiration date is when a version or family is scheduled to be removed from the Azure system completely.

trans-unit.source: Cloud services still running on a version when it expires will be stopped, deleted, or force upgraded to a newer version, as detailed in the [Azure Guest OS Supportability and Retirement Policy][retirepolicy].
trans-unit.target: Cloud services still running on a version when it expires will be stopped, deleted, or force upgraded to a newer version, as detailed in the [Azure Guest OS Supportability and Retirement Policy][retirepolicy].

trans-unit.source: Microsoft supports at least two recent versions of each supported Guest OS family.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft supports at least two recent versions of each supported Guest OS family.

trans-unit.source: The disable date of an existing Guest OS version could move to a later date to ensure at least two released versions remain enabled for deployment.
trans-unit.target: The disable date of an existing Guest OS version could move to a later date to ensure at least two released versions remain enabled for deployment.

trans-unit.source: > [AZURE.WARNING] The retirement of Guest OS family 1 began June 1, 2013 and is scheduled to complete soon.
trans-unit.target: > [AZURE.WARNING] The retirement of Guest OS family 1 began June 1, 2013 and is scheduled to complete soon.

trans-unit.source: Do not create new installations and upgrade older ones using this Guest OS family.
trans-unit.target: Do not create new installations and upgrade older ones using this Guest OS family.

trans-unit.source:
For more information see [Azure Guest OS Family 1 Retirement Information][fam1retire]
The Guest OS includes configuration different from the defaults of Windows Server.
trans-unit.target:
For more information see [Azure Guest OS Family 1 Retirement Information][fam1retire]
The Guest OS includes configuration different from the defaults of Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [Differences between Azure Guest OS and Default Windows Server][server and gos].
trans-unit.target: For more information see [Differences between Azure Guest OS and Default Windows Server][server and gos].

trans-unit.source: Guest OS Family, Version, and Release Explanation The Guest OS families are based on released versions of Microsoft Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS Family, Version, and Release Explanation The Guest OS families are based on released versions of Microsoft Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: The Guest OS is the underlying operating system that Azure Cloud Services run on.
trans-unit.target: The Guest OS is the underlying operating system that Azure Cloud Services run on.

trans-unit.source: Each Guest OS has a family, version and release number.
trans-unit.target: Each Guest OS has a family, version and release number.

trans-unit.source: The **Guest OS family** corresponds to a Windows Server operating system release that a Guest OS is based on.
trans-unit.target: The **Guest OS family** corresponds to a Windows Server operating system release that a Guest OS is based on.

trans-unit.source: For example, family 3 is based on Windows Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: For example, family 3 is based on Windows Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: A **"Guest OS version"** is the family OS image plus relevant [Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC)][msrc] patches available at the date the new Guest OS version is produced.
trans-unit.target: A **"Guest OS version"** is the family OS image plus relevant [Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC)][msrc] patches available at the date the new Guest OS version is produced.

trans-unit.source: Not all patches may be included.
trans-unit.target: Not all patches may be included.

trans-unit.source: Numbers start at 0 and increment by 1 each time a new set of updates is added.
trans-unit.target: Numbers start at 0 and increment by 1 each time a new set of updates is added.

trans-unit.source: Trailing zeros are only shown if important.
trans-unit.target: Trailing zeros are only shown if important.

trans-unit.source: That is, version 2.10 is a different, much later version than version 2.1.
trans-unit.target: That is, version 2.10 is a different, much later version than version 2.1.

trans-unit.source: A **"Guest OS release"** refers to a rerelease of a Guest OS version.
trans-unit.target: A **"Guest OS release"** refers to a rerelease of a Guest OS version.

trans-unit.source: A rerelease occurs if Microsoft finds issues during testing requiring changes.
trans-unit.target: A rerelease occurs if Microsoft finds issues during testing requiring changes.

trans-unit.source: The latest release always supersedes any previous releases, public or not.
trans-unit.target: The latest release always supersedes any previous releases, public or not.

trans-unit.source: The management portal will only allow users to pick the latest release for a given version.
trans-unit.target: The management portal will only allow users to pick the latest release for a given version.

trans-unit.source: Deployments running on a previous release are usually not force upgraded depending on the severity of the bug.
trans-unit.target: Deployments running on a previous release are usually not force upgraded depending on the severity of the bug.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, 2 is the family, 12 is the version and "rel2" is the release.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, 2 is the family, 12 is the version and "rel2" is the release.

trans-unit.source:
**Guest OS release** - 2.12 rel2
**Configuration string for this release** - WA-GUEST-OS-2.12_201208-02
The configuration string for a Guest OS has this same information embedded in it, along with a date showing which MSRC patches were considered for that release.
trans-unit.target:
**Guest OS release** - 2.12 rel2
**Configuration string for this release** - WA-GUEST-OS-2.12_201208-02
The configuration string for a Guest OS has this same information embedded in it, along with a date showing which MSRC patches were considered for that release.

trans-unit.source: In this example, MSRC patches produced for Windows Server 2008 R2 up to and including August 2012 were considered for inclusion.
trans-unit.target: In this example, MSRC patches produced for Windows Server 2008 R2 up to and including August 2012 were considered for inclusion.

trans-unit.source: Only patches specifically applying to that version of Windows Server are included.
trans-unit.target: Only patches specifically applying to that version of Windows Server are included.

trans-unit.source: For example, if an MSRC patch applies to Microsoft Office, it will not be included because that product is not part of the Windows Server base image.
trans-unit.target: For example, if an MSRC patch applies to Microsoft Office, it will not be included because that product is not part of the Windows Server base image.

trans-unit.source: Note 1 The August and September 2014 releases were partially rolled out due to issues found with an [MSRC patch][MS14-046] partway through release.
trans-unit.target: Note 1 The August and September 2014 releases were partially rolled out due to issues found with an [MSRC patch][MS14-046] partway through release.

trans-unit.source: The problem does not allow the manual install of .NET 3.5.1 on family 3 and 4.
trans-unit.target: The problem does not allow the manual install of .NET 3.5.1 on family 3 and 4.

trans-unit.source: The release was disabled as a precaution so customers could not manually select it.
trans-unit.target: The release was disabled as a precaution so customers could not manually select it.

trans-unit.source: Note 2 As of Sept 19, 2014, .NET 4.5.2 has not been specifically tested on the Azure Guest OS.
trans-unit.target: Note 2 As of Sept 19, 2014, .NET 4.5.2 has not been specifically tested on the Azure Guest OS.

trans-unit.source: But the Guest OS is essentially equivalent to Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: But the Guest OS is essentially equivalent to Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: The same compatibility rules that apply to the Windows Server product therefore apply to the equivalent Guest OS Families.
trans-unit.target: The same compatibility rules that apply to the Windows Server product therefore apply to the equivalent Guest OS Families.

trans-unit.source: If you encounter an exception to this policy, please contact [Azure support][azuresupport].
trans-unit.target: If you encounter an exception to this policy, please contact [Azure support][azuresupport].

trans-unit.source: Microsoft will give a commercially reasonable effort to resolve your issue.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft will give a commercially reasonable effort to resolve your issue.

trans-unit.source: [Manual install package for .NET 4.5.2][net install pkg].
trans-unit.target: [Manual install package for .NET 4.5.2][net install pkg].

trans-unit.source: MSRC Updates Included in Guest OS The list of patches that are included with each monthly Guest OS release is available [here][patches].
trans-unit.target: MSRC Updates Included in Guest OS The list of patches that are included with each monthly Guest OS release is available [here][patches].

trans-unit.source:
SDK Support
This table shows which Guest OS family is compatible with which Azure SDK versions.
trans-unit.target:
SDK Support
This table shows which Guest OS family is compatible with which Azure SDK versions.

trans-unit.source: For more information beyond this table, see [Support and Retirement Information for the Azure SDK for .NET and APIs][retire policy sdk].
trans-unit.target: For more information beyond this table, see [Support and Retirement Information for the Azure SDK for .NET and APIs][retire policy sdk].

trans-unit.source: Any information at this list supersedes the information below.
trans-unit.target: Any information at this list supersedes the information below.

trans-unit.source: > [AZURE.IMPORTANT] To ensure that your service works as expected, you must deploy it to Guest OS release that is compatible with the version of the Azure SDK used to develop your service.
trans-unit.target: > [AZURE.IMPORTANT] To ensure that your service works as expected, you must deploy it to Guest OS release that is compatible with the version of the Azure SDK used to develop your service.

trans-unit.source: If you do not, the deployed service may exhibit errors in the cloud that were not apparent in the development environment.
trans-unit.target: If you do not, the deployed service may exhibit errors in the cloud that were not apparent in the development environment.

trans-unit.source:
| Guest OS Family | SDK Versions Supported | | --------------- | ---------------------- | | 4 | Version 2.1 and later | | 3 | Version 1.8 and later | | 2 | Version 1.3 and later | | 1 | Version 1.0 and later |
## Guest OS System Update Process This page includes information on upcoming Guest OS Releases.
trans-unit.target:
| Guest OS Family | SDK Versions Supported | | --------------- | ---------------------- | | 4 | Version 2.1 and later | | 3 | Version 1.8 and later | | 2 | Version 1.3 and later | | 1 | Version 1.0 and later |
## Guest OS System Update Process This page includes information on upcoming Guest OS Releases.

trans-unit.source: Customers have indicated that they want to know when a release occurs because their cloud service roles will reboot if they are set to "Automatic" update.
trans-unit.target: Customers have indicated that they want to know when a release occurs because their cloud service roles will reboot if they are set to "Automatic" update.

trans-unit.source: Guest OS releases typically occur at least 5 days after the MSRC update release that occurs on the second Tuesday of every month.
trans-unit.target: Guest OS releases typically occur at least 5 days after the MSRC update release that occurs on the second Tuesday of every month.

trans-unit.source: New releases include all the relevant MSRC patches for each Guest OS family.
trans-unit.target: New releases include all the relevant MSRC patches for each Guest OS family.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure is constantly releasing updates.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure is constantly releasing updates.

trans-unit.source: The Guest OS is only one such update in the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The Guest OS is only one such update in the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: A release can be affected by a number of factors too numerous to list here.
trans-unit.target: A release can be affected by a number of factors too numerous to list here.

trans-unit.source: In addition, Azure runs on literally hundreds of thousands of machines.
trans-unit.target: In addition, Azure runs on literally hundreds of thousands of machines.

trans-unit.source: This means that it's impossible to give an exact date and time when your role(s) will reboot.
trans-unit.target: This means that it's impossible to give an exact date and time when your role(s) will reboot.

trans-unit.source: We will update the [Guest OS Update RSS Feed][rss] with the latest information we have, but consider that time an approximate window.
trans-unit.target: We will update the [Guest OS Update RSS Feed][rss] with the latest information we have, but consider that time an approximate window.

trans-unit.source: We are aware that this is problematic for customers and working on a plan to limit or time reboots.
trans-unit.target: We are aware that this is problematic for customers and working on a plan to limit or time reboots.

trans-unit.source: When a new release of the Guest OS is published, it can take time to fully propagate across Azure.
trans-unit.target: When a new release of the Guest OS is published, it can take time to fully propagate across Azure.

trans-unit.source: As services are updated to the new Guest OS, they are rebooted honoring update domains.
trans-unit.target: As services are updated to the new Guest OS, they are rebooted honoring update domains.

trans-unit.source: Services set to use "Automatic" updates will get a release first.
trans-unit.target: Services set to use "Automatic" updates will get a release first.

trans-unit.source: After the update, you’ll see the new Guest OS version listed for your service in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: After the update, you’ll see the new Guest OS version listed for your service in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Rereleases may occur during this period.
trans-unit.target: Rereleases may occur during this period.

trans-unit.source: Some versions may be deployed over longer periods of time and automatic upgrade reboots may not occur for many weeks after the official release date.
trans-unit.target: Some versions may be deployed over longer periods of time and automatic upgrade reboots may not occur for many weeks after the official release date.

trans-unit.source: Once a Guest OS is available, you can then explicitly choose that version from the portal or in your configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Once a Guest OS is available, you can then explicitly choose that version from the portal or in your configuration file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Update the Azure Guest OS from the Management Portal][update guest os portal] and [Update the Azure Guest OS by Modifying the Service Configuration File][update guest os svc].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Update the Azure Guest OS from the Management Portal][update guest os portal] and [Update the Azure Guest OS by Modifying the Service Configuration File][update guest os svc].

trans-unit.source: For a great deal of valuable information on restarts and pointers to more information technical details of Guest and Host OS updates, see the MSDN blog post titled [Role Instance Restarts Due to OS Upgrades][restarts].
trans-unit.target: For a great deal of valuable information on restarts and pointers to more information technical details of Guest and Host OS updates, see the MSDN blog post titled [Role Instance Restarts Due to OS Upgrades][restarts].

trans-unit.source: If you manually update your Guest OS, please read the [Guest OS retirement policy][retirepolicy].
trans-unit.target: If you manually update your Guest OS, please read the [Guest OS retirement policy][retirepolicy].

trans-unit.source: Guest OS Supportability and Retirement Policy The Guest OS supportability and retirement policy is explained [here][retirepolicy].
trans-unit.target: Guest OS Supportability and Retirement Policy The Guest OS supportability and retirement policy is explained [here][retirepolicy].

trans-unit.source:
News Archive
###### **Nov 11, 2014**
The November release (4.14, 3.21, and 2.33) was rolled out November 11th.
trans-unit.target:
News Archive
###### **Nov 11, 2014**
The November release (4.14, 3.21, and 2.33) was rolled out November 11th.

trans-unit.source: This update was pushed earlier because it includes the MSRC update [Microsoft Security Bulletin MS14-066 - Critical][MS14-066].
trans-unit.target: This update was pushed earlier because it includes the MSRC update [Microsoft Security Bulletin MS14-066 - Critical][MS14-066].

trans-unit.source: Your web and worker roles on automatic update should reboot once over the next few days and receive this fix.
trans-unit.target: Your web and worker roles on automatic update should reboot once over the next few days and receive this fix.

trans-unit.source: ###### **Nov 10, 2014** The October release (4.13, 3.20, and 2.32) disable date has been updated based on customer feedback.
trans-unit.target: ###### **Nov 10, 2014** The October release (4.13, 3.20, and 2.32) disable date has been updated based on customer feedback.

trans-unit.source: The disable date will always be at least two months from the release date.
trans-unit.target: The disable date will always be at least two months from the release date.

trans-unit.source: ###### **Nov 4, 2014** The October release (4.13, 3.20, and 2.32) was rolled out Nov 4, 2014.
trans-unit.target: ###### **Nov 4, 2014** The October release (4.13, 3.20, and 2.32) was rolled out Nov 4, 2014.

trans-unit.source: It includes the MSRC patch which caused problems with the August and September releases.
trans-unit.target: It includes the MSRC patch which caused problems with the August and September releases.

trans-unit.source: To get around this problem, the October release includes .NET 3.5 and 3.5.1 preinstalled, but disabled.
trans-unit.target: To get around this problem, the October release includes .NET 3.5 and 3.5.1 preinstalled, but disabled.

trans-unit.source: Scripts attempting to install .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 will effectively re-enable it and return a "success" for the .NET installation, but also avoid the full install problem created by the MSRC patch.
trans-unit.target: Scripts attempting to install .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 will effectively re-enable it and return a "success" for the .NET installation, but also avoid the full install problem created by the MSRC patch.

trans-unit.source: **Oct 20, 2014. Updated Nov 4, 2014** - The September release (4.12, 3.19, 2.31, and 1.39) partially rolled out due to the same [MSRC patch MS14-046][MS14-046] causing failures for those attempting to install .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 on family 3 or 4.
trans-unit.target: **Oct 20, 2014. Updated Nov 4, 2014** - The September release (4.12, 3.19, 2.31, and 1.39) partially rolled out due to the same [MSRC patch MS14-046][MS14-046] causing failures for those attempting to install .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 on family 3 or 4.

trans-unit.source: .NET 3.5.x is NOT officially supported on either family, but Microsoft is responding to the change in behavior because some customer's installations do rely on it and the change was unannounced.
trans-unit.target: .NET 3.5.x is NOT officially supported on either family, but Microsoft is responding to the change in behavior because some customer's installations do rely on it and the change was unannounced.

trans-unit.source: The disable dates of previous Guest OSes (June and July) will be delayed accordingly so that at least two fully released Guest OSes are supported and available.
trans-unit.target: The disable dates of previous Guest OSes (June and July) will be delayed accordingly so that at least two fully released Guest OSes are supported and available.

trans-unit.source: A solution for the .NET install problem appeared in the October 2014 release.
trans-unit.target: A solution for the .NET install problem appeared in the October 2014 release.

trans-unit.source: The October release includes .NET 3.5 and 3.5.1 preinstalled (but disabled), and also include the MSRC patch listed previously.
trans-unit.target: The October release includes .NET 3.5 and 3.5.1 preinstalled (but disabled), and also include the MSRC patch listed previously.

trans-unit.source: Scripts attempting to install .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 will effectively re-enable it and return a "success" for the .NET installation, but also avoid the install problem created by the MSRC patch.
trans-unit.target: Scripts attempting to install .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 will effectively re-enable it and return a "success" for the .NET installation, but also avoid the install problem created by the MSRC patch.

trans-unit.source: Because of the partial rollout of the last two releases, people on auto update or who have rolled out new installations may be on any of these Guest OS releases.
trans-unit.target: Because of the partial rollout of the last two releases, people on auto update or who have rolled out new installations may be on any of these Guest OS releases.

trans-unit.source: The following table lists which Guest OS releases allow the installation of .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 on family 3 and 4.
trans-unit.target: The following table lists which Guest OS releases allow the installation of .NET 3.5 or 3.5.1 on family 3 and 4.

trans-unit.source: Currently, if a release allows installation, that means it does NOT have MSRC patch MS14-046 installed.
trans-unit.target: Currently, if a release allows installation, that means it does NOT have MSRC patch MS14-046 installed.

trans-unit.source:
| OS Version | Can install .NET 3.5 | Includes MSRC patch [MS14-046][] | | --- | --- | --- | | All later Guest OS versions | Yes | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.13_201410-01 | Yes | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.12_201409-02 | No | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.12_201409-01 | No | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.11_201408-02 | Yes | No | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.11_201408-01 | No | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.10_201407-01 | Yes | No |
**Oct 20, 2014** - Because August and September release were only partially rolled out, you should note the following:
1.
trans-unit.target:
| OS Version | Can install .NET 3.5 | Includes MSRC patch [MS14-046][] | | --- | --- | --- | | All later Guest OS versions | Yes | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.13_201410-01 | Yes | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.12_201409-02 | No | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.12_201409-01 | No | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.11_201408-02 | Yes | No | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.11_201408-01 | No | Yes | | WA-GUEST-OS-4.10_201407-01 | Yes | No |
**Oct 20, 2014** - Because August and September release were only partially rolled out, you should note the following:
1.

trans-unit.source: The cipher changes outlined in Differences between Azure Guest OS and Default Windows Server have not been rolled out across the entirety of Azure.
trans-unit.target: The cipher changes outlined in Differences between Azure Guest OS and Default Windows Server have not been rolled out across the entirety of Azure.

trans-unit.source: Customers not on the August or September releases will receive these changes in the October release.
trans-unit.target: Customers not on the August or September releases will receive these changes in the October release.

trans-unit.source: The August and September Guest OSes have been disabled in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: The August and September Guest OSes have been disabled in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You cannot manually choose them.
trans-unit.target: You cannot manually choose them.

trans-unit.source: This is to protect against issues that could arise if you select this Guest OS version.
trans-unit.target: This is to protect against issues that could arise if you select this Guest OS version.

trans-unit.source: The disabled dates of some earlier releases have been adjusted forward.
trans-unit.target: The disabled dates of some earlier releases have been adjusted forward.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure continued availability in the portal and support for at least two released Guest OS versions in each family.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure continued availability in the portal and support for at least two released Guest OS versions in each family.

trans-unit.source: Made public Oct 18.
trans-unit.target: Made public Oct 18.

trans-unit.source:
